executive_summary: The Painting industry has fared relatively well in the past few years, painting over the stain of COVID-19 and housing market fluctuations. When the economy fell apart in 2020, painting stood as one of the few in-person jobs without massive layoffs, owing to the industry's liberal use of personal protective equipment, respirators and ventilated workspaces. Construction crews experiencing similar conditions kept working as soon as restrictions allowed, cutting into a significant shortfall in residential properties and demanding paint services.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COVID-19 Inflicts Damage, But Painters Remain Strong
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Caught between the economic disaster of the pandemic and an unexpected housing market explosion, most paint contractors survived the year with only minor setbacks. Thousands of smaller paint contractors exited the industry, but unemployed entrepreneurs picked up the discarded brushes and got to work. Once the worst was over, paint supply caught back up with demand and the industry recovered almost completely by mid-2021.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Painters Compete With Public Health for Safety Equipment
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: When the pandemic struck, many painters were thrilled to find that painting safety tools fell under national and local recommendations to limit viral spread. Many painters used stores of respirators, masks, bodysuits, fans and other equipment to help medical response teams and protect employees. When these supplies ran out, painters either went without or halted operations. Upon the return of protective equipment supplies, painters in work outfits were protected from viral transmission, improving their appearance to clients.

Despite making a powerful aesthetic statement, wallpaper and wallpaper hanging is a dying art. The minimalist movement and other similar clean design motifs shy away from wallpaper and towards the simple elegance of monochromatic paint. Paperhangers are also much rarer than painters and charge a premium.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Painters Supplement Wall Covering With Coating Services
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Like other construction-adjacent industries, the most successful painters earn money even while the paint is drying. Companies with technical experience are partnering with virtual reality developers to help clients visualize the look of a painted room, while other.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Housing Crises Looms Large Atop Painting Industry
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Players are building internal cost-management systems or reputation management teams. Larger operators have also built tools for independent painters, including crew communication networks and lead generation apps. When the market for houses is thrown into chaos, painters spend more money locating contracts instead of on inputs, and the resulting contracts themselves are typically much smaller. Shocks in the Chinese market with the collapse of major developer Evergrande have further shaken confidence in housing, despite most of the bankrupt company's portfolio being located in China. Until this market corrects, painting demand will slowly decline and painters will have to wait out the storm.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Painters Will Struggle With Low Home Improvement Spending
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Home improvement projects will also be put on hold while the housing market struggles. Many homeowners borrow against the value of their home to finance improvement projects, hoping for a net return. Unfortunately for all but the wealthiest property owners, these investments are a massive risk.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Home improvement stores will also struggle to generate demand and may reduce operations, threatening supply.
N O N R E S I D E N T I A L  P R O J E C T S  G R O W  S T E A D I LY
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: With consumer spending still high, companies have the financing capacity for larger offices and manufacturing facilities. A rise in business activity will heighten turnover rates for productive spaces, generating income for painters on each rental contract. Nonresidential markets remain relatively stable despite the challenges in other construction spheres.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: D I G I T A L  T O O L S  S T A N D A R D I Z E  P A I N T I N G  O R G A N I Z A T I O N  F R O M S O L O  P A I N T E R S  T O  M U LT I - T E A M  C O N T R A C T O R S
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The contract painting industry in the U.S. is putting a second coat onto the use of digital platforms for commerce and exposure, replacing the word-of-mouth system painters have used for decades. Adopting technologies such as online booking platforms, mobile quoting tools, and Client Relationship Management (CRM) systems has propelled the industry, particularly smaller contractors without dedicated support staff, towards an increasingly organized future. These technological advancements have streamlined administrative tasks and standardized customer experience through instant bookings. However, inherently digital avenues may put less tech-savvy contract painters at a competitive disadvantage; many of the most skilled coating applicators.

industry_definition: The Painters industry includes operators primarily engaged in interior or exterior painting and interior wall covering. The painting and wall covering work performed includes new work, additions, alterations, maintenance and repairs. Enterprises in this industry perform activities ranging from bridge and ship painting to removing paint and wall coverings.
key_trends: Competition among painters is highly localized and relatively weak.
Building contractors will select painters based on reputation, team size and price.

Coating applicators must typically be approved by a manufacturer to work with many hazardous, niche or complicated products. Only a fraction of coating specialists is approved in each city, eliminating competitive losses.
Painters hid the stain of COVID-19 with additional coats on houses while the nonresidential market sagged. Now, as the market reverses,

Painters use almost the same technology as the first cave paintings from tens of thousands of years ago. However, coating applicants and paperhangers require significantly more capital, more safety equipment, and command higher premiums.
Painters are sensitive to changes in the labor market
No companies hold significant market share

More customers are opting for low-maintenance, high-durability coating products, despite their higher cost and more minimalist aesthetic. Paperhangers have been driven nearly to extinction, while new coatings are popping up all over the place for every built surface.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Residential building markets consist of any unit that an owner or renter considers their residence. Standalone houses, multiplexes, apartments and condos are all included, as are supplementary painting services for these structures (logistics, for example).

Nonresidential painting applies to any human-occupiable structure not considered a residence and includes all logistics and coating services for these structures. Offices, commercial spaces, restaurants, schools and gyms create the most nonresidential contracts.

Nonbuilding coatings are applied to any structure not designed to support sustained occupancy or to vehicles, in addition to related logistics. Painters in this market color and coat fuel pipelines, planes, boats, sewage stations and other essential service infrastructure.

products_and_services.product_or_service: PAPER HANGING, WALL COVERING AND REMOVAL

tier_1_suppliers: Tool & Hardware Wholesaling in the US
Truck & Bus Manufacturing in the US
Storage & Warehouse Leasing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Apartment & Condominium Construction in the US
Commercial Building Construction in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Protecting the value of a housing asset
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Protecting the value of a housing asset is as easy as applying a can of paint. In addition to increasing the aesthetic of a property (and its price), a quality paint job provides water-resistance, UV protection and other protective attributes.

business_locations.location: Housing Buildout on the West Coast
business_locations.location_description: Higher housing demand on the United States West coast attracts painters looking for high-paying contracts in wealthy neighborhoods. Elevated cost of living in this area increases payments on rent, purchases and other inputs. However, the West's stable climate reduced the number of jobs available for coating providers.

business_locations.location: MID-ATLANTIC SPECIALIZES IN COATING AND SPECIALTY SERVICES
business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic's concentration of specialty industries and utility providers creates demand for special coating providers. Apartment living also generates income for painters – units are repainted more frequently with the high tenant turnover in these buildings.

business_locations.location: GREAT LAKES PAINTERS BECOME CONTRACTED IN THE AUTOMOTIVE SECTOR
business_locations.location_description: Despite the Great Lakes falling as the automotive capital, many vehicles are produced nearby. Painters might cover cars with a ceramic clear-coat or apply rust-preventing coatings to cars before shipping.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH ADMINISTRATION (OSHA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) identifies several dangers present to painters, including fire, spark-induced explosions, fume inhalation and toxic chemical buildup; breaking these rules results in a fine exceeding $14,500. Operator costs to mitigate these threats remain low, with respirators, coveralls, fans and electrical grounding equipment available at nearly every hardware store.

Constructing a new building quickly requires combined efforts from a revolving door of contractors; by limiting occupancy of buildings during the pandemic, housing projects stalled and the entire industry just watched paint dry for weeks at time instead of earning revenue. These regulations were lifted in 2021 with vaccine distribution, though managers are hesitant to return to the house-building parties of 2019.

Especially for spray paint application and coating application, workers are encouraged to wear masks to inhibit inhaling hazardous aerosolized paint. Once COVID-19 restrictions relaxed enough to restart painting, painters had to make only slight modifications to their breathing setups to comply with the new mandates.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry assistance level is low and steady.

basis_points.basis_description: Competition among painters is highly localized and relatively weak. Building contractors will select painters based on reputation, team size and price.

concentration_points.concentration_title: The pandemic leaves many jobless and looking for painting opportunities
concentration_points.concentration_description: As a stereotypical, low-skill entrepreneur venture, many newly unemployed people attempted to start painting careers as COVID-19 raced across the country. Many new painting operations quickly folded, but the surviving companies added to an industry already stuffed with one- and two-person teams.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Specialist coating companies go out of business with economic downturn
concentration_points.concentration_description: While the housing boom of 2020 saved many painters from packing their brushes, industrial coating companies weren't as lucky. Large-scale project cancellations put coating contracts for utilities and vehicles into limbo, while higher employee compensation started piling up, leaving the smaller companies to pick up the slack.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Waste Disposal, Insurance and Invoicing Comprise Unique 'Other' Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Paint cans can't be thrown in the trash in most regions; instead, operators must pay for hazardous waste disposal. Costs for basic business services, including invoicing, insurance and registration, are also relatively high for many small painting businesses.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: While this industry is relatively labor-intense, both employee and equipment costs are among the lowest in the economy. Skilled painters can easily complete whole-house painting contracts solo and the most massive pipeline coating projects might require a team of a few dozen people.

volatility_points.volatility_title: PAINT COMPANIES POWERLESS TO LOWER PRICES AGAINST VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: As supply chain crises swept the nation in 2020 and 2021, large companies across the economy fought back. Unfortunately for the painting industry, half of painting companies are either one or two people and must accept the sticker price at Home Depot or Lowe's.

volatility_points.volatility_title: WILD OIL PRICES SHAKE UP PAINT SUPPLY COSTS
volatility_points.volatility_description: Clients desiring a long-lasting, highly durable product return to oil-based paint instead of its latex (water)-based competition. The Texas freeze (and power failures) of 2021, the Russia-Ukraine conflict, OPEC production cuts and national green energy policy each diverted oil from paint production despite high construction demand, raising prices and biting into financial reserves.

volatility_points.volatility_title: HOUSING BUBBLE GROWS DURING THE PANDEMIC AND DEFLATES IN 2022
volatility_points.volatility_description: House painters are having flashbacks to 2008, as 2020's seemingly unstoppable housing boom is falling apart in a matter of weeks. 98.0% of all United States housing markets noticed prices rising 45.0% since 2019, with buyers in Florida and California paying an additional $1,000 every.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Residential Painters Are Saving With Paint And Primer Combos
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: A decade ago, a painter needed to carry at least two buckets: one for the top color coat, and one for a primer, which helped the paint adhere. New paint mixes have combined paint and primer into a single can for each color, and painters can apply two color coats for equivalent results. For unique surface materials or the most superior paint job, a quality primer can still help, though residential painters in particular have adopted this time and money-saving strategy.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Electric Paint Rollers Provide Precise Rollers With The Speed Of Sprayers
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: While paint sprayers can coat a surface more quickly than one person with a roller, prepping for intense overspray takes almost as long. By running a tube to siphon paint up into the head of a roller and adding a paint pump to the other end, a painter can now precisely control application while not having to dip into a paint tub every few minutes.

FAQs.question: COVID AND MASKING RESTRICTIONS
FAQs.answer: Especially for spray paint application and coating application, workers are encouraged to wear masks to inhibit inhaling hazardous aerosolized paint. Once COVID-19 restrictions relaxed enough to restart painting, painters had to make only slight modifications to their breathing setups to comply with the new mandates.

FAQs.question: THE PAINTING CONTRACTORS ASSOCIATION
FAQs.answer: For nonemployer-dominated professions, trade shows and expos are essential in bringing everyone up to speed on the newest technology, best practices and forging business connections. The Painting Contractors Association holds these meetings, in addition to offering more unusual services, including a collective healthcare plan, jobs portal and training for members.

FAQs.question: Which construction markets does your company primarily work with? How easily can your company switch between the residential and nonresidential construction markets?
FAQs.answer: Operators in the Painters industry primarily work with residential and nonresidential construction clients and can switch between these markets, depending on the size of their operations.

FAQs.question: How much does your company participate in remodeling activities?
FAQs.answer: Operators in the Painters industry are usually focused on both new work and remodeling activities.

FAQs.question: How does your company compete for contracts with larger businesses?
FAQs.answer: Most large operators in the industry compete on the basis of quality, especially for lucrative contracts with large projects. These operators typically do not lack the capacity to deliver on more lucrative projects. Working as a subcontractor for a larger construction project may help smaller operators to break into more lucrative markets in commercial and industrial painting. However, the regulations and costs associated with these projects are also much higher.

FAQs.question: Have productivity issues ever kept your company from winning lucrative contracts over larger competitors?
FAQs.answer: Lucrative contracts are typically awarded to larger contractors that have the resources to complete a quality job in a specific time for the right price. Larger contracts are more likely to go to companies that can demonstrate quality, communication and speed in addition to simply having enough labor. By focusing on quality, small teams might be able to beat larger, more inefficient contractors for projects.

FAQs.question: How much does your company invest in new equipment annually?
FAQs.answer: Investment in new technology is usually fairly low among builders and contractors. If a firm's contracts typically involve painting or coating large, flat, outdoor areas, investing in a paint sprayer can dramatically improve project speed. Depreciation is very low in this industry. Therefore, any investments are likely to still be valuable in many years.

FAQs.question: How have recent regulatory expenses affected your company's profitability?
FAQs.answer: While regulatory expenses have not significantly affected company profitability, industry participants must hold licenses to carry out business within certain states and territories. Ensuring compliance with workplace safety standards is critical to earning repeat business and avoiding worker injury.

FAQs.question: How does your company work with local or national trade associations to advance its interests?
FAQs.answer: Some trade associations, such as the Painting and Decorating Contractors of America, offer training courses for operators, in addition to holding members to certain industry standards.

FAQs.question: How many of your company's clients are return customers?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators have a varied amount of return customers. For larger projects, such as fireproof coating painting, a company may have a return customer since they specialize in that field. Focusing on long-term partnerships is likely to be more lucrative than looking for the best individual jobs, while also providing more stability.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profitability compare with that of its competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins vary depending on input prices and painting demand. Smaller operators have lower profit margins, while larger contractors with multimillion dollar contracts experience higher profit margins.

FAQs.question: How does your company promote loyalty and to keep its customers returning? What kinds of special discounts or high-caliber client experiences does your company offer?
FAQs.answer: Establishing a loyal customer base is integral for long-term success in this industry. Maintaining high-quality workmanship and developing word-of-mouth referrals strengthens a loyal customer base. Besides customer service, the quality of paint and speed of application can also help earn repeat contracts.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure its prices are attractive to customers? How does your company compete with other companies based on pricing?
FAQs.answer: Much of the work generated in this industry is on a tender basis, and successful contractors look to win tenders based on competitive pricing and an established reputation for quality. Identifying advantages firms have over any competitors routinely bidding on the same contracts can help firms get more profitable jobs while minimizing costs.

FAQs.question: How does servicing a range of clients affect your company's costs? How has your company broken into different markets?
FAQs.answer: The capacity to operate across a wide range of markets (e.g. housing, commercial, maintenance and repair) and shift the business's focus toward specific markets based on demand helps ensure a steady workflow.

FAQs.question: How does your company's spending on employee-related expenses compare to the industry average? How has your company implemented strategies to minimize these costs?
FAQs.answer: Monitoring the labor market may help companies to improve hiring decisions and minimize this cost.

FAQs.question: How much of your company's revenue comes from working on private homes? How can your company capture more of consumers' rising income?
FAQs.answer: Growth in household disposable income stimulates demand for alterations and maintenance for single-family homes. For large companies with excess capacity, devoting some resources to the home improvement market can be a relatively easy way to diversify income sources.

FAQs.question: How does your company monitor housing construction trends? How can your company build real estate relationships to paint more new homes?
FAQs.answer: As more houses are built, demand for painting services will increase.
